text:
Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: CHAS. B. RILEY
Present Address: MAIR SASK
Pioneer Address: ROSE PLAIN

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1905

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE:

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 14

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Weekly

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sundays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Many times

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) No

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Sometimes coffee

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place? All went

6. Did you ever have "teas" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Tell what you remember about such gatherings, stating dates if possible, telling what the teas were for, and how often they occurred.

Once a year for our dance, probably my 18th birthday

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There were quite a few dances in the house until we moved to a larger house on 11th Street. I remember one 11th Street dance, a lot of young ladies. I remember one 11th Street dance, a lot of young ladies. I remember one 11th Street dance, a lot of young ladies.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Yes

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
PIONEER RECREATION AND SOCIAL LIFE

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

5. What time of the day did you go—in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "make potlucks" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

6. Did you ever have "meets" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activities?

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes?

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times—every two weeks, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas trees, promiscuous etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire.)

9. When was your first community hall built? 1928

What material was it made of? wood

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? community

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? country

To what extent did it take the place of houses or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local schoolhouse for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings?)

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 3), how, and why, did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for? They were left outside.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular? Very popular

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, Picnics, etc.)

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

10. What material was it made of? How large was it? 30x66

11. Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? 

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? If so, how often? If not, why not?

Did you continue to use the hall for other functions after the school closed? If so, what were they?

12. When parties, dances, etc., were held in houses, school houses or halls (as referred to by question 3, 9, and 11) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

13. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for prizes?

What dances were popular?

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings?

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
3.

12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? School reunions with formal dinner, followed by a dance, and the small trip and promenade.

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? Describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc., and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or entertainments not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Shriners' Club in your community? When was it organized, and what steps led to its organization?

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it? How many women belonged? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Handwritten notes:

- Year 1909 organized Homemakers Club 1912.
- Start 1911
- Year 1912
- Need a library Community Christmas dinner organized. This was our in 1912 and more.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swanky," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? School conducted little formal ceremony.

13. Was the church known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about churches, telling how communities were connected with them, etc.: Church was central to community life.

Followed by a church, school, and town hall.

14. Describe any other details of meetings, parties, etc., that you remember, telling at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life's became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS:

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community? The Homemakers Club.

Give the date and purpose for its being organized.

June 1909 organized Homemakers Club.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community? Yes

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

About 1911

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

90%

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

People's Bank, credit union, old timers' club, 1912.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

Had a library Community Christmas dinner organized. This was our in 1912 and others.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town, village, or county. Mention all organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here.

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? [Handwritten]

20. Were you accustomed to having several information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? [Handwritten]

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? [Handwritten]

Give dates if possible. 1909

Who provided the lantern and the slides? [Handwritten]

That were the slides about? [Handwritten]

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? [Handwritten]

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? [Handwritten]
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before this, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included only children or only adults, whether it was religious, charitable, educational, etc.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to hearing special information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, what were they about? Who gave them? How often were they attended? Any other details you remember?

21. What games did boys play in summer? (Baseball, marbles, etc.)

22. What games did girls play in summer? (Skating, etc.)
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families," "Whist," checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? 

Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? 

Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, etc., or other objects or animals or games in the snow? 

Describe them.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 

Give year and month if possible.

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? 

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

10 o'clock, 8, 9 at night
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families," "Mushers," or others? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? 

Did anyone usually play with some kind of work? 

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? 

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, stones, or other objects? 

PIONEERS AND SPORTS 

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 

Give year and month if possible. 

26. Who organized it? 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held? 

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups' aground dinner? 

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last? 

10 o'clock to 9 at night
33. Describe any features of this place which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of activities which you knew of in the early days, such as skating parties, skating races, etc. Tell about all the activities, family food and drink, when held, etc.

The only thing was the community picnic. It was held yearly.

35. What changes have you noticed in pioneer times since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

40. When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

March built around the 10 mile
33. Describe any features of this place which you remember as outstanding.

The only feature was the community picnic. It was held every year.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the school, town, or club picnic.

There were no changes.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

There were no changes.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people), how they were played, etc.

Young people played baseball, basketball, and football. The men played hockey and curling.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Football (women)

What year?

1907

How long did it continue?

1913

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

The Eagle Town Hall team. They had an organized team to play for a couple of years and won all games. They also had a curling team.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Men built over the 18 mile...
7.

10. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1914

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Yes

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

When was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st). July 4th

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates. No

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

Tom Hur. Tom Hur. Tom Hur. Tom Hur.

Paul Clifford Paul Clifford Paul Clifford Paul Clifford

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? All

What kind of books and how many? A community library was started about 1911 but has not been distributed.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Occasionally

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Yes, I purchased

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Yes

Give details and dates: The travelling library from the province of Ontario was sent by the government of Ontario to the school district of

48. Was there a school library? Yes

When was it begun? 1906

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? Not much

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Not much
10. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1914
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
   Then was the sports day usually held what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 4th?

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball, or other teams? Give names and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible; if not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? all
    What kind of books and how many? One book, about 1911 but has been here since then.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? extensively

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details. Yes, I bought

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? Yes
    When was it begun? 1906
    To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? Not much

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes.

When was it started? 1911

Who started it? Mr. H.

Is it still in existence? Yes

If not, when was it discontinued, and why? 1925 and moved

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, who it was kept by, who acted as librarian, how much money was raised for borrowing books, etc.

About 30 books. Mrs. H. Patten (Poveshell), was librarian.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

Oklahoma Farmer
South Dakota Farmer
Western Home Monthly
Mr. West Texas

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Yes

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

I have quite a few books on history on the 1700s.

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

On our way west and back every Sunday in summer which was also a social gathering and well attended.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes.

When was it started? About 1911

Is it still in existence? Yes

If not, when was it discontinued, and why? 1925 and moved

Give any other data (in which you can show how many books it contained, how many people used it, how much money was raised for borrowing books), who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

About 30 books. Mrs. N. Bath, (President), was librarian.

51. Have newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Yes

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. On the way to go
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Piano, and about 608

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violin, lot of it.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, places if possible, and tell where you bought them.

9 October 1910 - 1913 - 1915 - Flute

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your house entertainment in early years in the West? Describe. There was a piano.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Red River Valley, Old Folks at Home

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. No, there was a musical band here.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody? Because of some special happening in the community? Explain. Yes, I made up a song on our new school building.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes, when it started?

Who started it?

How long did it continue?

How many were in it?

Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Piano, and about 6-8

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Guitar, grand piano, organ, violin, etc.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

9 October 1910 - 910 - 1913 $55 - How much?

59. How large a part did skating and other forms of music play in your house entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? Red Wing, After All, etc.

61. Was "Cock music," or music of the country you came from, popular in your house or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody? Because of some special happening in the community?

63. Was there a band in your community? Who started it? How long did it continue?

How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
10.

64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is there an important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections" such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, how many and what are they?

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

65. Is there an important or less important event in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

66. Have you any "collections," such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Please describe them briefly.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird watching, etc.?

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

Oxford
